content: darksol diminutive devil king pattern by villaimmersus dark dragon s revival is at hand the millennium nightmare will continue the land will shudder the people will suffer yet heroes would rise to stand against the devil king-- oh he s a bit smaller than expected still keep your wits about you his small and unexpectedly cute form still holds great evil darksol is a ruthless villain originally from the game shining force the legacy of great intention for the sega genesis/mega drive notions worsted weight yarn category 4 g/6-4 25 mm hook - gray j/10-6 00 mm hook - red yarn needle - blue stuffing - white scissors or snips stitch markers optional notes pattern uses u s crochet terms and assumes the reader is already familiar with how to work basic crochet stitches pattern is also worked in continuous rounds unless specified finished piece is about five inches 12 7 cm high finished project size can be scaled up or down by scaling both the yarn and hook size optional place a stitch marker at the last stitch of the round to track stitch counts as you progress through the pattern replace the marker at the last stitch of the current round abbreviations yarn-over = yo back bump = bb yarn-under = yu increase = increase chain = chain change color = cc single_crochet = single_crochet back loop/back loop only = bl/blo half-double_crochet = half_double_crochet invisible decrease = inv decrease double_crochet = double_crochet bind off = bobble magic_ring = magic_ring invisible join = inv join darksol diminutive devil king 1 special stitches and techniques magic_ring magic_ring take the yarn and make a loop running counter-clockwise so the tail falls over the loop hold the tail and the loop together with the off-hand bring the hook through the loop and the tail yo and pull up a loop commence with pattern working over both the loop and the tail once all the stitches in the magic_ring are completed pull the tail of the loop to close the magic_ring yarn-under yu crocheting with yarn-unders will create a slightly tighter fabric and reduce the natural lean in the stitches than when using yarn-overs yo to do a yarn-under insert the hook into the next stitch but do not wrap the yarn around the hook yarn is under the hook crocheting into the back bump bb on a chain there are three loops the top loops which are the front and back loops that are normally worked into and the back bump on the underside of the chain working stitches into the back bump creates a tighter first row than if the stitches were worked normally on either or both of the top loops i e the gaps around the stitches are smaller and the fabric doesn t stretch as much however the trade-off is that it can be more difficult to insert the hook into the chain invisible join inv join after
